name: Shop Heroes
description: Craft legendary items, gear up your heroes for epic quests, and fight for the top of the Trade Wars and PvP Leaderboards in the original smash hit fantasy tycoon: Shop Heroes!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Memory: 512 MB RAM

reviews.review_text: A perfect, genuine free game. You are allowed to peacefully manage your shop. No blood, no zombies, no violence, no boring cliches that all other developers are using nowadays.  Finally a game where the focus is on cooperation. You may build your city together with a bunch of friends. There is no 'real' pvp in the game. Of course you may compare yourself to others in many ways. But that is really pointless here. This is a peaceful manager game.  Yes, there is an in-game currency that you can buy from devs. But thats reasonable. Of course they have to earn some money do keep up the good work. You wouldn't work for free either. Would you? Also an important feature is that you are allowed to earn that currency in the game so easily. So you may still play without paying a single cent without any restrictions. Very nicely balanced. Still I advise to back the devs a bit. :) They deserve it.  The support is very helpful, and they are acting fast, when you contact them. You may link your steam based account and your phone account to a single shop. That way you may visit your business even if you are not close to your PC.  I strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes to chill out in a peaceful environment.
A fun casual game. You don't have to buy the in-game purchases to enjoy it. Easy to play while do other things or while playing another game.

This game was developed as a mobile game, so there is a lot of waiting around for items to be finished, quests to be completed, etc. A lot of people have been complaining about this. I, however, have found myself very busy within the game while timers are running down, and I have put a lot more time into the game than some negative reviewers (which means the timers are longer for me). Yes, there are micro-transactions, but I have played the game for days without feeling the need to purchase anything extra. This game is so fun, though, that I would be completely fine spending a bit of money on it - I've had more enjoyment out of it than some Steam games I've bought for $20 or more!  Overall, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who asked. :)

This game was originally an Android/Facebook game. It's definitely a game where you're able to pay to win, but it's also a nice casual game for me to come back to periodically, which is nice for my ADD. Gather resources, make more items, increase the size of your shop, join a city, participate in raids weekly. It's not something you'll spend hours a day playing, but it's great to kill a few minutes while you're waiting on something else, in the restroom, or just bored.  I prefer the Steam version to the Facebook version (FB was super laggy and had to be refreshed periodically) and this one feels more like what I'm used to on my phone, just with a bigger screen, and easier to play while still looking busy and not as if I'm definitely goofing off on my phone.

I love the fact that the devs have gone out of their way to make this game playable and sync-able across different platforms. There's instructions from the devs on how to contact them to link your Android/iOS/FB game account with your Steam account, and best of all when I did so, they responded within 2 hours.  Gamewise, it's a pretty standard shop simulator, but more forgiving than say Diner Dash. It may get a little grindy after a while, but then again all games do so. Better still, it doesn't need to be paid constant attention once you get to the higher levels, so you can leave it on in the background and just come back to check it once in a while.
Fun and Adictive, when you have free time this game can eat all this one. You can do everything with the free version and grow up to be a massive and wonderfull shop.

Despite Steam showing my amount of time played, I have probably logged over 100 hours on the iOS version. It is a mobile game in the same style as Recettear, so the comparisons others have made are apt.  I have personally enjoyed the game though, as unlike Recettear it is best when groups work together for mutual benefit. The bonuses obtained through City guides are quite helpful, and they are free. In fact, the whole game can be played from free, though it takes some extra work to build up gems, the IAP. There are other F2P games that follow similar formuls, so in the end it comes down to fun, and I find the game enjoyable.  Pros: Working together in a group Free* Can be played in small increments or continous micromanagement, both styles of play supported Fun (subjective) Arenas (PvP) That Diablo feeling when you finally find or craft a legendary item.  Cons: Free* but spending some actual money helps. With that said, it is not too difficult to build a steady stream of free gold.  Can be incredibly difficult playing solo. Group play is pretty much a requirement. Group bonuses make the game more enjoyable and faster crafts  Some minor gripes - turning furniture only turns in two directions, not in all four Lack of avatar customization without high IAP - Similar to other games, but still sucks Missing some aspects that make Recettear so enjoyable - More shop customization, plyable missions

Shop Heroes seems pretty different to most idle games, so it definitely has that going for it. I like it, but I know the gems and wait to complete system will have tons of people turned away from it because of its pay to win vibe. That being said its pretty standard for mobile/ Facebook ports to have that kind of system, and while I myself cant fully enjoy a game that has it there are tons of people who do. If you are a fan of idle games, dont mind timer and think you might enjoy shop keeping gameplay then I would recommend you try Shop Heroes. On the other hand if you do not like mobile ports, timers, or the idea of a game where you sell items to adventurers this is a game to avoid.

A cute, very addictive fantasy-themed simulator.  The main premise is being a shop keeper. Making items to sell to customers and equip your own band of heroes with.  But it's also pretty encompassing. At the same as running an adventurer supply store, you are also establishing and building a town around your base of operations to bring in more varied wares, specialized workers, supply chain, customers, heroes, and quests.  Yes, it does have microtransactions, but they seem to be entirely for speeding up the simulation. You can easily just go slow and steady and accomplish everything in the game regardless, so the cash shop is entirely for convenience, not necessity.  And since it's free then anyone who loves fantasy RPG type town building, shop keeping, crafting should probably give it a whirl just to enjoy a fresh spin on things. At the very least it's definitely worth that.

I've played this game for several months now on another platform so ignore my 4 hrs here. Yes it's a FB game. No it is not a microtransaction money grab.   Almost all items in the game that are not cosmetic can be gained by spending no money. Yes there are some blueprints (used to craft items) that can be in cash packages, they look cool, but there is a free item that is just as good. Yes you can use cash to speed things up if you like but it does not unbalance the game at all. I have played for about 4 months on FB and spent $19.99 not because I needed to but because I want to support the game and liked the items I got.  You can earn premium gems by sending your heroes on missions, doing city raids every weekened, and you can sell any item you craft for permium gems.   Ok enough of the money stuff. It's free to play period, don't listen to the folks with 0.3 hrs on record that didn't bother to try out the best parts of the game. Or just downvote it because it's a FB/Phone game. The build here on Steam already has things implemented that are not on other platforms yet.   The devs are great, they listen to the comunity and keep us informed about what is going on. They are very responsive to any concerns and seek to solve problems quickly.   If you like crafting in MMOs this game is for you. You run a shop where you craft items to sell to heroes or to other players. You send your heroes on missions to gather items to craft with though not all items need them. You can fight other players in the arena if you like. Join a city and work with others to build your town up to unlock all the heroes and workers you need. Raid with your city weekly to earn premium gems and box keys. Browse the player market for good deals and resell for a profit.  The most important thing is to join a good city. It expands the game play and lets you evolve your shop faster.

I see a lot of people complain about some pretty random things in the game. I've been playing for months now... on my phone. Now, I wish they'd let me play the Facebook version on Steam, and apparently they're working on it, so I'm going to assume everything is the same on both.  For one thing, the microtransaction money is TRADABLE and can be earned in game through advertisements and certain quests. You don't have to spend money, but if you do, there is an awesome deal where you get 3000 for $10, which is more than enough to do anything you wanna really do. Now, its 100 for 30 days, but its the most for your money. But like I said, you can trade for gems, so don't sweat it. Watch the markets and see what people are willing to toss a gem down for. Especially if you manage to get a rare recipe, you'll get gems for the products. The crafting times get a bit long, but there are ways to combat it and honestly... what are you doing sitting there staring this game down for to begin with? Play something else. This isn't League of Legends where you have to sit there 30-50 minutes at a time. Play this briefly during your queue times! Relax... there is no rush to do a bunch of stuff here.

After spending over 500 hours on this, i think the game is a fairly decent way to pass some of your free time. I mainly play PC games and don't own a mobile device, so I'm glad to see these types of games offered here on Steam.  The microtransactions don't have to be that painful, unless you are the type of completionist who cares about earning every gold star. You can gain a decent amount of free gems by playing the game co-operatively. After you reach level 15 in the game, (probably less than 24hrs of gameplay required), you can earn gems from other players using the global Trade House. The best use for early gems, is to get gold, any amount of gold that you gain can speed up your progress tremendously.  If you feel you can manage to reward the devs at Cloudcade a little for thier work, the Fountain of Gems offers 100 gems per day for 30 days, which seems the best deal at $9.99USD for 30 days. As I mentioned you can earn a Gold Star, if you manage to hire all 20 available workers. Sadly gaining that star will cost you close to $100USD for the two premium workers.  It's beneficial to be in a city by yourself for the first 20 levels or so, and then joining a mid-level city will give more advantages. Every city buiding gives some type of passive bonus, and an instant bonus when you invest in the building. The investment costs for a solo player are going to be much lower, which makes it much easier to take advantage of those bonuses.

I tried very hard to get into this game. No, honestly, I did. And it remains to be seen whether I'll go back to it. I really enjoy casual games and wouldn't mind dropping a few quid on a good one.  The problem is... it just doesn't feel like there's much to it. Craft items. Sell items you've crafted. Craft more items. Run out of resources to craft more items. Send heroes on quests (which effectively are just timers and nothing else) to find out if the Random Number Gods will give you the resources you need to craft more items. Wait. Find out you didn't get the resources. Wait some more.  I've played for just over an hour, and for the first half-hour, there was very little waiting. The second half-hour was pretty much solid wait city. I like the fact that games like this are available for the PC, it's so much easier to click than tap. But this one is just not for me. It remains to be seen if I'll go back to it, but I don't think I will.
